title: How to Start Doing Photography

steps.headline: Choose a camera according to your comfort level.
steps.description: If you're just starting out with photography, choose a point and shoot or digital single-lens reflex (DSLR) camera that you feel comfortable handling. It doesn't matter how many megapixels it can capture or how expensive it is. Start with what's affordable and buy used gear as you learn more. Consider purchasing a refurbished camera that you can learn on. Regardless of what type of camera you buy, it's important to read the owner's manual. This will teach you about features that are unique to your camera. EXPERT TIP																															Or Gozal																Photographer								Or Gozal has been an amateur photographer since 2007. Her work has been published in, most notably, National Geographic and Stanford University's Leland Quarterly. Or Gozal			Photographer				You don't need anything fancy to learn the foundations. Or Gozal, photographer, tells us: "A simple camera is great for learning the basics and getting a solid foundation. For tighter budgets, experimenting with phone photography first is perfectly fine! If you’re ready to get a camera, though, an entry-level DSLR is a good way to go. I started out with a Canon Rebel T3; in the current market, I’d pick a Canon T6i or a Nikon D3300."

steps.headline: Purchase a prime lens if you have a DSLR camera.
steps.description: To have more control over your images, specifically the light and blurring of the background, use a prime lens. This lens is fixed so it doesn't zoom. A prime lens is useful when you're still learning how to balance aperture, shutter speed, and image sensitivity. A common prime lens to start with is a  50mm 1.8.

steps.headline: Buy several memory cards so you have backup storage.
steps.description: It's easy to think that if you have 1 large memory card, you're all set. Unfortunately, memory cards can become lost or stop working over time. Purchase a few memory cards in different storage sizes and keep a few in your camera bag so you always have access to memory. Memory cards usually last between 2 and 5 years, so you'll need to replace them occasionally.

steps.headline: Get a tripod to capture crisp images.
steps.description: Purchase an inexpensive tripod that you can secure your camera to. The tripod will stabilize your camera so you can take shots with a longer shutter speed without getting blurry images. For example, you can take pictures in the evening when the lighting is low. If you can't buy a tripod, set up a stack of books or place your camera on a flat post to steady it.

steps.headline: Store your gear in a camera bag.
steps.description: Get a camera bag or backpack that holds your camera, any lenses you want to carry, and your tripod. Ensure that the bag is comfortable to carry around or you'll be less likely to actually use it. Most camera bags have small compartments for lenses, filters, and memory cards.

steps.headline: Install photo-editing software on your computer.
steps.description: Editing your images on the computer is a large part of creating great pictures. Choose a photo-editing software that has tools you think you'll need in post-production, such as adjusting color balance and playing with contrast. Capture One Pro, Adobe Lightroom, and Photoshop are popular photo-editing programs. Make sure the image you take is not blurry.

steps.headline: Photograph things that inspire you.
steps.description: Find what you're really passionate about photographing and spend lots of time taking pictures of it. Instead of trying to take perfect pictures, try to capture what made you excited about the shot or what sparked delight. For example, if you love to travel, take pictures of everything on your trip. Over time, you might find that you're particularly drawn to photographing architecture or people that you meet.

steps.headline: Work on composing your shots.
steps.description: As a beginner, take photographs of everything that draws and holds your attention. Pay attention to what's in your camera's viewfinder before you capture the image. A classic photography trick is to compose the picture by the rule of thirds. Imagine your frame is divided into thirds going horizontally and vertically. Then place interesting subjects along these lines. For example, instead of taking a photograph of a tree in the middle of your frame, move the camera so the tree is off to the bottom left of the frame and you can see the valley behind it. If you'd like to take an extremely close up photograph of something, such as a flower or bug, use your camera's macro mode. This will allow you to capture rich details.

steps.headline: Adjust the distance between your subject.
steps.description: Once you've found something you'd like to photograph and composed a shot, take a few pictures. Then move closer to the subject so it fills the frame and take a few more pictures. Walk around to photograph from different angles and then walk farther away from your subject. You might find that photographing even closer or farther away will give you a better image than the one you imagined. This is a great trick to try if you're struggling to come up with a shot. Just start moving around your subject until something catches your eye.

steps.headline: Play around with the exposure triangle to have more control.
steps.description: You'll probably start taking photos using your camera's automatic settings. Keep shooting automatic until you're ready to start learning more and being more creative. When you start photographing in manual, you'll be able to control aperture, shutter speed, and image sensitivity. These work together to determine the quality of the photo you take.Tip: If the manual is overwhelming, try focusing on just 1 element at a time. For example, make aperture a priority setting before combining other exposure settings. For example, imagine you want to photograph a track race. If you shoot in automatic, the camera will probably freeze the action to create a still image. If you'd rather take a picture where the runner is blurred and appears to be moving fast, use manual to slow the shutter speed.

steps.headline: Find time to practice as much as possible.
steps.description: The best way to improve your photography skills is to photograph as often as you can. To make things interesting, give yourself challenges and show your photos to a photography mentor or friend. For example, challenge yourself to photograph action shots one day. Photograph nature scenes the next day. Then shoot food or fashion images the following day. Consider enrolling in a photography class or taking a workshop where you can get one-on-one feedback.

steps.headline: Play around with different styles of photography.
steps.description:
If you're thinking about a career in photography, you may already know what style of photography you want to do. If not, spend time trying a variety of styles. For example, focus on:
Fine art
Fashion
Food and product styling
Nature and landscape
Family and events
Photojournalism

steps.headline: Build a solid portfolio of your best work.
steps.description: Once you've accumulated a lot of images that you're proud of, pick 10 to 20 of them to become your portfolio. Include photos that you can show to potential clients. Keep in mind that your portfolio should highlight the style of photography that you want to do for a living. Consider having a physical portfolio that you can look through with clients, as well as an online portfolio that you can direct them to.

steps.headline: Share your work on social media.
steps.description: Be as active as possible on social media, such as Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Regular posts and images will earn you a large following that can earn you valuable work. Remember to direct viewers to your website so they can order prints or hire you. Some photographers prefer to focus on social media before building a solid portfolio. Since there's no wrong or right way to approach this, do what feels comfortable to you.

steps.headline: Learn the business aspects of being a professional photographer.
steps.description: If you're seriously considering a photography career, keep in mind that you'll be doing a lot of other things in addition to photographing. Decide if you're comfortable with balancing these demands or if you'd like to find a business partner.Tip: It helps to have experience with bookkeeping, website creation, and social media. Photographers need great people skills since you'll be interacting with clients.

steps.headline: Set realistic goals for yourself.
steps.description: It's easy to feel frustrated if your photography career isn't taking off as quickly as you thought it would. To help you chart your progress, create a mixture of short term and long-term goals that are achievable. Set deadlines for some of the goals to hold yourself accountable. For example, tell yourself to photograph 3 weddings within 1 year. A long-term goal might be photographing weddings every weekend during the summer.
